TITLE:
   Chief Complaint: Hypoxia
   24 Hour Events:
 INDWELLING PORT (PORTACATH) - START [**2130-12-10**] 11:30 AM
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2130-12-10**] 05:44 PM
 NASAL SWAB - At [**2130-12-10**] 06:01 PM
 EKG - At [**2130-12-10**] 06:33 PM
 ARTERIAL LINE - START [**2130-12-10**] 09:04 PM
 EKG - At [**2130-12-10**] 10:00 PM
   Was brought back to ICU for new-onset hypoxia.  Was found to have
   diffuse ground-glass appearance to lungs on CT scan.  Hypoxia worsened
   and he was intubated.  .   Had a bronchoscopy which was unrevealing for
   cause other than small amount of bleeding.  He became hypotensive and
   tachycardic to 160.  Stayed in sinus.  Was treated with fluid boluses
   until started to develop pulmonary edema.  Lopressor 15 was given,
   which helped bring heart rate down.  Levophed was started for MAP of
   58, he did not respond so phenylephrine and vasopressin started.  Urine
   output has dropped off, but his resp picture is improving.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Piperacillin - [**2130-12-9**] 02:00 AM

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:22.0/42.7/2.1, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:56//0.04, ALT / AST:16/34, Alk Phos / T Bili:74/1.6, Amylase
   / Lipase:/9, Differential-Neuts:88.1 %, Lymph:7.3 %, Mono:3.4 %,
   Eos:1.0 %, Lactic Acid:2.4 mmol/L, Albumin:2.4 g/dL, LDH:267 IU/L,
   Ca++:7.1 mg/dL, Mg++:1.8 mg/dL, PO4:2.1 mg/dL  On transfer: Labs
   notable for WBC of 17, lactate of 6.0.
   CTA
   IMPRESSION:
   1. No evidence of pulmonary embolus.
   2. Interval development of widespread patchy ground-glass opacities.
   Given
   the rapidity of onset, this most likely represents an atypical
   infection or
   drug reaction.
   3. Increased mass-like thickening of the distal esophagus compared to
   the
   [**Month (only) 319**] PET scan, with minimal interval increase in size of prevascular
   lymph
   nodes and gastroesophageal lymph nodes. There is ascites and a nodular
   appearance of the mesentery, which may be due to worsening hepatic
   failure,
   but is also concerning for carcinomatosis.
   4. Stable biilateral pleural effusions.
   BAL, Ascites, and Sputum: NTD
   Urine: small amount of probable enterococcus
   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially thought to be PE and patient
   was started on Heparin despite guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent
   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for
   hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Continue broadened coverage to Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime (expanded GI and
   GNR coverage) as well as Vanc, Zosyn, Azithro
   - Q2 MDIs PRN
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves
   .
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs
   they may have
   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, start tube feeds
   #Prophy: pneumoboots, heparin TID, type and screen
   #Code status: Full Code
   #Communication: Patient; brother is health care proxy
   #Dispo: pending clinical stability
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following information:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxia. He was initially thought to have pulmonary embolism (PE) and was started on heparin, but a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) showed no evidence of PE. The patient's condition worsened, and he was intubated and placed on an ARDSnet protocol. A bronchoscopy was performed to evaluate for hemorrhage and obtain a bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sample.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 7.2-13.0 K/uL
* Hct: 32.5-33.9%
* Plt: 49-71 K/uL
* Cr: 0.7-0.9 mg/dL
* TropT: <0.01-0.04 ng/mL
* TCO2: 20-23 mmol/L
* Glucose: 104-246 mg/dL

The patient's physical examination shows:

* Peripheral vascular: Not assessed
* Skin: Not assessed
* Neurologic: Responds to stimuli, movement, and tone not assessed

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl (Concentrate) - 1,140 mcg/hour
* Midazolam (Versed) - 7 mg/hour
* Norepinephrine - 0.25 mcg/Kg/min
* Vasopressin - 2.4 units/hour
* Phenylephrine - 1.5 mcg/Kg/min
* Metoprolol - [**2130-12-10**] 09:34 PM

The patient's potential medical complications include:

* Hypoxia and respiratory failure
* Sepsis or septic shock
* Cardiac failure or cardiogenic shock
* Hepatic failure or liver disease
* Kidney failure or acute kidney injury
* Electrolyte imbalance
* Anasarca or edema
* Infection or pneumonia
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or hemorrhage

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential infections
* Vasopressors to support blood pressure
* Sedation with fentanyl and midazolam
* Close monitoring of blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygen saturation
* Repeat laboratory tests and imaging studies as needed
* Consultation with cardiology and hepatology teams
* Notification of oncology team regarding admission and treatment plan

   2. Interval development of widespread patchy ground-glass opacities.

   3. Increased mass-like thickening of the distal esophagus compared to

   lymph
   nodes and gastroesophageal lymph nodes. There is ascites and a nodular
   appearance of the mesentery, which may be due to worsening hepatic

   but is also concerning for carcinomatosis.
   4. Stable biilateral pleural effusions.
   BAL, Ascites, and Sputum: NTD

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially thought to be PE and patient
   was started on Heparin despite guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent
   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for
   hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Continue broadened coverage to Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime (expanded GI and
   GNR coverage) as well as Vanc, Zosyn, Azithro
   - Q2 MDIs PRN
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves
   .
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs
   they may have

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C who was readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxia. The patient's condition has rapidly deteriorated, and he is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98.1°F)
* Heart rate: 87-160 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/54 mmHg (68/48 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 98%
* White blood cell count: 17,000 cells per microliter (μL)
* Lactate level: 2.4 mmol/L

The patient has a diffuse ground-glass appearance on CT scan, which is concerning for an atypical infection or drug reaction. He has also developed widespread patchy ground-glass opacities, which may be related to an infection or inflammation.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 17,000 cells/μL
* Hct: 32.5%
* Platelet count: 49,000 cells/μL
* Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 2.4 mmol/L
* Albumin: 2.4 g/dL
* LDH: 267 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.1 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.1 mg/dL

The patient's medical history is significant for esophageal cancer, hepatitis C, and a recent episode of paracentesis.

The patient's current medications include:

* Piperacillin/Tazobactam (Zosyn)
* Ciprofloxacin
* Cefepime
* Vancomycin
* Fentanyl
* Midazolam
* Norepinephrine
* Vasopressin
* Phenylephrine

The patient's potential medical complications include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate level and WBC count suggest the possibility of sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxia and respiratory acidosis may progress to respiratory failure if not treated promptly.
3. Cardiac failure: The patient's elevated troponin-T level and decreased ejection fraction may indicate cardiac failure.
4. Hepatic failure: The patient's elevated liver enzymes and decreased albumin level suggest the possibility of hepatic failure.
5. Renal failure: The patient's elevated creatinine level and decreased urine output may indicate renal failure.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's abnormal electrolyte levels (hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia) may contribute to his respiratory and cardiac instability.
7. Infection: The patient's widespread patchy ground-glass opacities and elevated WBC count suggest the possibility of an infection.
8. Pulmonary edema: The patient's elevated pulmonary artery wedge pressure and decreased lung compliance may indicate pulmonary edema.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover potential infections
2. Vasopressors to support blood pressure
3. Mechanical ventilation to support respiratory function
4. Fluid management to prevent fluid overload
5. Sedation with fentanyl and midazolam to manage pain and anxiety
6. Echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function
7. Blood glucose monitoring to manage glycemic control
8. Nutrition support with tube feeds
9. Prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcer
10. Repeat DFA to monitor respiratory status.

   was started on Heparin despite guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent
   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for
   hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Broaden coverage to Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  This should cover
   atypicals, gm (+) and gm (-)
   - nebulized treatments q 4 hours
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   - Stat KUB looking for perf d/t recent paracenteses
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves
   .
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine if has dosing for renal failure
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although

Summary:

The patient, a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet protocol. The initial impression was that the patient had pulmonary embolism, but the CTA was more consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) from peritonitis or pneumonia. The patient had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and evaluate for hemorrhage. The patient was also found to have a low urine output, tachycardia, and anasarca.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Pneumonia: The patient's symptoms and radiological findings are consistent with pneumonia, which is a common complication in patients with esophageal cancer.
2. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate levels are indicative of sepsis, which can be caused by a variety of factors, including pneumonia, peritonitis, or other infections.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of esophageal cancer and hepatitis C may increase the risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
4. Liver failure: The patient's anasarca and elevated bilirubin levels suggest that the patient may be at risk for liver failure, which can be a complication of hepatitis C.
5. Renal failure: The patient's low urine output and elevated creatinine levels suggest that the patient may be at risk for renal failure, which can be a complication of sepsis or other medical conditions.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to pneumonia, ARDS, or other causes, and may require continued mechanical ventilation.
7. Hemorrhage: The patient's bronchoscopy findings suggest that the patient may have hemorrhage, which can be a complication of pneumonia or other respiratory infections.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs and laboratory results to assess for signs of sepsis, cardiac complications, liver failure, renal failure, and respiratory failure.
2. Consider broadening the patient's antibiotic coverage to include coverage for atypical organisms, gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, and fungi.
3. Continue to provide supportive care, including mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and fluid management.
4. Consider performing a stat KUB to evaluate for perfusion defects in the setting of recent paracentesis.
5. Consult with the patient's oncologist to determine if any of the patient's chemotherapy drugs may be contributing to the patient's symptoms.
6. Consider referring the patient to a gastroenterologist or hepatologist to evaluate the patient's liver disease and provide guidance on treatment.

   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Hypoxic Respiratory failure: Initially thought to be PE and patient
   was started on Heparin despite guaiac positivity.  CTA more consitent
   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for
   hemorrhage.  Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Continue broadened coverage to Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime (expanded GI and
   GNR coverage) as well as Vanc, Zosyn, Azithro
   - Q2 MDIs PRN
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs
   they may have

Summary:

The patient, a 58-year-old male with esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated and started on ARDSnet protocol. Initial concerns included pulmonary embolism, but subsequent CT scan revealed a diffuse ground-glass appearance to the lungs, consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to peritonitis or pneumonia. The patient was also found to have hypotension with lactic acidosis, likely due to sepsis, hypovolemia, or cardiogenic shock. He is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, vasopressors, and sedation.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's hypotension, lactic acidosis, and elevated lactate levels suggest the possibility of sepsis. Sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's ARDS is likely due to peritonitis or pneumonia, which can lead to further respiratory failure and potentially require mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiac Complications: The patient's hypotension and lactic acidosis may be indicative of cardiac dysfunction, including cardiogenic shock. Cardiac complications can lead to further organ dysfunction and increased mortality.
4. Liver Failure: The patient's hepatitis C and liver disease may progress to liver failure, which can lead to further complications, including coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and increased risk of infection.
5. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient's esophageal cancer and peritonitis may lead to gastrointestinal complications, including bleeding, perforation, and obstruction.
6. Infection: The patient's broad-spectrum antibiotics and antiviral therapy may not be effective against all potential pathogens, increasing the risk of infection and further complications.
7. Multi-Organ Failure: The patient's complex medical condition and multiple organ dysfunction may lead to multi-organ failure, which can be life-threatening.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, including ABG and FiO2, and adjust ventilator settings as necessary.
2. Broaden antibiotic coverage to include Gram-negative and anaerobic pathogens.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status, including EKG and troponin levels, and adjust therapy as necessary.
4. Treat liver disease based on recommendations from hepatology.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and replete as necessary.
6. Consider transferring the patient to a liver transplant center if liver failure is suspected.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and provide adequate caloric and protein support.

   with ARDS from peritonitis or PNA  (viral or PCP) , hemorrhage,
   aspiration, or influenza versus Pulmonary edema from fluid shifts after
   paracentesis, aggressive resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx
   and recent normal echo.  Patient was intubated and put on ARDSnet
   protocol.  He had a bronchoscopy to obtain BAL and eval for hemorrhage.
    Stopped heparin because not found to have PE on CTA
   - Follow-up BAL results
   - Continue broadened coverage to Vanc/Cipro/Cefepime (expanded GI and
   GNR coverage) as well as Vanc, Zosyn, Azithro
   - Q2 MDIs PRN
   - Continue to monitor ABG
   - Sedation with Fentanyl/Midazolam
   - BNP & Echo to evaluate for heart failure
   - EKG, Cardiac Enzymes
   - Repeat DFA
   # Hypotension with lactic acidosis: Patient's BP ranging from 80s to
   130s systolic, representing pain, and possible underlying sepsis with
   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.
   He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of malnutrition,
   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.
   - Broaden ABx as above
   - Continue to monitor lactate
   - See above cardiac work-up
   # Tachycardia: Sinus tachycardia, likely representing underlying
   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He was intubated and placed on ARDSnet protocol. The patient's hypoxia worsened, and he developed pulmonary edema. He received fluid boluses, vasopressors, and inotropes to manage his blood pressure and heart rate. His urine output decreased, but his respiratory status improved.

The patient's medical history includes esophageal cancer, hepatitis C, and liver disease. He has a history of paracentesis and aggressive resuscitation, which may have contributed to his fluid shifts and pulmonary edema. The patient's laboratory results show elevated lactate levels, indicating possible underlying sepsis or hypovolemia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated lactate levels and tachycardia may indicate underlying sepsis, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
2. Hypovolemia: The patient's decreased urine output and hypotension may indicate hypovolemia, which could lead to further cardiovascular compromise.
3. Cardiogenic Shock: The patient's elevated troponin levels and decreased ejection fraction may indicate cardiogenic shock, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
4. Pulmonary Edema: The patient's pulmonary edema may worsen if he continues to receive fluid boluses or if his heart failure worsens.
5. ARDS: The patient's diffuse ground-glass appearance on CT scan and pulmonary edema may indicate acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), which could worsen his respiratory status.
6. Liver Failure: The patient's liver disease and elevated bilirubin levels may indicate liver failure, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.
7. Infection: The patient's elevated white blood cell count and C-reactive protein levels may indicate infection, which could worsen his respiratory and cardiovascular status.

Based on the patient's history and laboratory results, it is essential to closely monitor his respiratory and cardiovascular status and to manage his fluid and electrolyte balance carefully to prevent further complications.

   resuscitation or decreased EF.  No cardiac hx and recent normal echo.

   elevated lactate.  DDx: Sepsis vs. hypovolemia vs. cardiogenic shock.

   liver disease, and cancer.  Lactate elevated from hypoxia, high work of
   breathing and poor liver clearance.

   - Continue to monitor lactate

   - Wean from pressors as able to
   - Albumin 50g
   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Low UOP: likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   Fluid overload and affecting resp status so no boluses at this time.
   BUN/Cr suggests pre-renal origin
   - Boluses with fluid when resp status improves

   sympathetic drive to breath and pain.  Was given NS boluses to improve
   hydration.  Resp status stable.
   - Fluids when able to tolerate
   - Repeat EKG
   - Continue Mexilitine if has dosing for renal failure
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - Treat liver disease based on recs from hepatology
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - Notify Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] and the onc team about admission and f/u any recs

   - email Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] to see if any of chemo drugs could be contributory

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He has developed bilateral pulmonary opacities on CXR, and a CT scan suggests acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) or acute lung injury. The patient has a high suspicion of sepsis, with elevated WBC count, lactate, and BNP. He is intubated and on ARDSnet protocol. The patient also has hypotension, tachycardia, and low urine output, which may be related to shock, sepsis, or hypovolemia. He has a dilated colon, ascites, and nodular mesentery, which may be related to liver disease or carcinomatosis.

Potential medical complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count, lactate, and BNP suggest sepsis, which can lead to organ failure, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
2. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's bilateral pulmonary opacities on CXR and CT scan suggest ARDS, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.
3. Shock: The patient's hypotension, tachycardia, and low urine output suggest shock, which can lead to organ failure and death.
4. Liver failure: The patient's ascites, nodular mesentery, and elevated liver enzymes suggest liver failure, which can lead to coagulopathy, encephalopathy, and death.
5. Cardiac failure: The patient's elevated BNP and echo findings suggest cardiac failure, which can lead to cardiovascular collapse and death.
6. Infection: The patient's C. diff-negative stool culture and pending blood and urine cultures suggest infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ failure.
7. Constipation: The patient's dilated colon and obstipation suggest constipation, which can lead to bowel obstruction, perforation, and death.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's bilateral pulmonary opacities on CXR and CT scan suggest pneumonia, which can lead to respiratory failure and death.

These potential complications require close monitoring and management to prevent progression and improve the patient's outcomes.

   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.

   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.
   #Access: L IJ, A line, chemo port and PIV.

   distension.

The patient's condition is complex and multifaceted, with several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is ventilator-dependent and has a high risk of developing respiratory failure due to his underlying chronic lung disease and recent respiratory distress.
2. Septic shock: The patient has a high risk of developing septic shock due to his underlying liver disease, cancer, and recent respiratory failure.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are stable, but he has a high risk of developing acute kidney injury due to his underlying liver disease and recent respiratory failure.
4. Constipation: The patient has a distended colon and is at risk of developing constipation, which can exacerbate his respiratory failure and increase his risk of developing septic shock.
5. Pneumonia: The patient has a high risk of developing pneumonia due to his underlying chronic lung disease and recent respiratory failure.
6. Liver failure: The patient has underlying liver disease and is at risk of developing liver failure, which can exacerbate his respiratory failure and increase his risk of developing septic shock.
7. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient did not respond to a cortisol stim test and is at risk of developing adrenal insufficiency, which can exacerbate his respiratory failure and increase his risk of developing septic shock.
8. Malnutrition: The patient is malnourished and is at risk of developing further malnutrition, which can exacerbate his respiratory failure and increase his risk of developing septic shock.

To manage these potential medical complications, the patient is being treated with antibiotics, vasopressors, and other medications to address his respiratory failure, septic shock, and constipation. He is also being monitored closely for any signs of worsening respiratory failure, septic shock, or other complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS, septic shock, oliguria resolved, cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. He is sedated and unable to provide a medical history. The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, pressors, and steroids. His vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.2°F, heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 124/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His laboratory results show anemia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated lactate levels. He has a history of cirrhosis and is at risk for bleeding and infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and history of cirrhosis make him at risk for bleeding complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding and intracranial hemorrhage.
2. Infection: The patient's septic shock and elevated lactate levels suggest that he may be at risk for further infection. He is receiving antibiotics, but the cultures are pending.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure/ARDS may progress, leading to further respiratory compromise.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's septic shock and coagulopathy may lead to cardiac complications, including arrhythmias and cardiac arrest.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's septic shock and coagulopathy may lead to neurological complications, including seizures and stroke.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's cirrhosis and history of bleeding may lead to gastrointestinal complications, including ascites and encephalopathy.
7. Renal complications: The patient's oliguria resolved, but he may still be at risk for renal failure, especially if he develops further sepsis or bleeding.
8. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may worsen, leading to further complications, including hypotension and cardiovascular collapse.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastrointestinal status. Further evaluation and treatment of his sepsis, cirrhosis, and coagulopathy are also necessary to prevent further complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 58-year-old man with hypoxemic respiratory failure, septic shock, oliguria, cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. He is currently on mechanical ventilation, with a PEEP of 15 cmH2O and FiO2 of 50%. He is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, antivirals, and vasopressors.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.8°C (98.2°F)
* Heart rate: 74 bpm (range: 74-92 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 124/64 mmHg (range: 99/57-139/76 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 24 inspirations per minute (range: 15-24 inspirations per minute)
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 17.5 (range: 12.4-6.3)
* Hematocrit: 33.9 (range: 30.0-24.9)
* Platelet count: 84 (range: 62-33)
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL (range: 0.9-0.8 mg/dL)
* Troponin-T: 0.02
* Lactic acid: 2.2 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.1 g/dL
* LDH: 597 IU/L
* Calcium: 7.7 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.8 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 2.1 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies show:

* Chest CT: pending
* Abdominal CT: pending

Based on the patient's condition, potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate, leading to further hypoxia and hypercapnia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may progress, leading to organ dysfunction and failure.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may worsen, leading to hypotension and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis may progress, leading to further liver dysfunction and complications.
6. Infection: The patient may develop further infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, or bloodstream infections.
7. Organ failure: The patient may develop organ failure, including renal failure, hepatic failure, or cardiac failure.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory status with mechanical ventilation and adjust PEEP and FiO2 as needed.
2. Continue to treat the patient's septic shock with vasopressors and antibiotics.
3. Monitor the patient's coagulopathy and bleeding complications closely.
4. Continue to manage the patient's adrenal insufficiency with steroids and electrolyte replacement.
5. Monitor the patient's cirrhosis and liver function closely.
6. Perform further imaging studies, including CT scans, to evaluate the patient's condition.
7. Consider colonoscopic decompression or CT-guided drainage for the patient's ascites.
8. Wean the patient's pressors and vasopressors as tolerated.
9. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust replacement therapy as needed.
10. Consider transfer to a higher level of care, such as an intensive care unit or a step-down unit, for further management.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Continue treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t grim clinical
   scenario
   - NPO for now
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.
   - f/u ID recs.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.
   .

   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, holding tube feeds because of colonic
   distension.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C. He was readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure, which has developed over the last 12 hours.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: He is ventilator-dependent on assist control and has new, extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia.
* Colonic distension: His abdomen is distended, and CT scan with contrast confirmed no anatomic obstruction. The C. difficile test is negative.
* Hypotension: He has been able to come off of pressors except for Levophed, and his lactate has improved to normal range. His hypotension is multifactorial, likely due to sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, and liver disease.
* Low urine output: This has improved with improving hemodynamics, and creatinine is stable.
* Anasarca/liver disease: This is likely due to liver disease, although some cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out.
* Esophageal CA: This is thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and 5-FU.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Continuing Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro antibiotics to cover atypical pneumonia.
* Repeating sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA and bacterial culture.
* Continuing nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
* Weaning Levophed further as tolerated.
* Fluticasone 0.05 and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.
* Albumin 1g/kg today.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk of developing sepsis due to his respiratory failure, colonic distension, and hypotension.
2. Pneumonia: The patient's CT scan shows extensive ground-glass opacities, which may indicate atypical pneumonia.
3. C. difficile colitis: Although the C. difficile test is negative, the patient's colonic distension and diarrhea may still be caused by C. difficile infection.
4. Liver failure: The patient's liver disease may worsen, leading to liver failure.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's hypotension and anasarca may be due to cardiac involvement, which could lead to cardiac complications such as heart failure or arrhythmias.
6. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's malnutrition and liver disease may lead to nutritional deficiencies, which could worsen his condition.
7. Infection: The patient's multiple lines and indwelling devices may increase his risk of developing infections.
8. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and cardiac instability may lead to hemodynamic instability, which could worsen his condition.

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his outcomes.

s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed

   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.

   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.

   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.

   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C. He was admitted to the ICU with acute onset respiratory distress and has been experiencing worsening hypoxia over the past 12 hours. His current condition is characterized by:

* Respiratory failure: Ventilator-dependent on assist control, with new extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia.
* Colonic distension: Partially improved with rectal tube placement, with a diagnosis of obstruction, C. diff-mediated megacolon, and acute pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome).
* Hypotension: Improving, with a multifactorial cause including sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, and liver disease.
* Low urine output: Improving, with a possible cause of ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
* Anasarca/liver disease: Most likely due to liver disease, although some cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged ventilator dependence, respiratory acidosis, and possible development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Colonic distension: Continued colonic distension, potential perforation, and sepsis.
3. Hypotension: Adrenal insufficiency, liver disease, and sepsis may worsen, leading to cardiovascular instability and shock.
4. Low urine output: Continued oliguria, potential acute kidney injury, and possible need for dialysis.
5. Anasarca/liver disease: Progressive liver disease, ascites, and potential development of hepatic encephalopathy.
6. Esophageal cancer: Recurrence or progression of esophageal cancer, potentially leading to further respiratory and gastrointestinal complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor and manage respiratory failure, colonic distension, hypotension, and low urine output.
2. Consider decompression of the colon to alleviate distension and reduce the risk of perforation.
3. Continue antibiotics and antifungals to cover potential pulmonary and abdominal sources of infection.
4. Consider adding corticosteroids to manage adrenal insufficiency and potential liver disease-related complications.
5. Monitor liver function tests and consider referral to hepatology for further management of liver disease.
6. Continue to monitor and manage esophageal cancer-related complications, including potential recurrence or progression of the disease.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male admitted to the ICU with shock, respiratory failure, and other comorbidities. The patient's condition has improved substantially with hemodynamic management, steroids, and time.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a PEEP of 8 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and a tidal volume of 410 mL. The patient's respiratory status may continue to deteriorate if not closely monitored, leading to further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a history of septic shock and is receiving antibiotics. Sepsis can lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including acute kidney injury, liver failure, and cardiovascular instability.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has a coagulopathy, which increases the risk of bleeding complications, particularly with invasive procedures.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient is receiving steroids for adrenal insufficiency, and the dose may need to be adjusted based on the patient's response.
5. Oliguria: The patient's urine output is decreased, which may indicate acute kidney injury or prerenal azotemia. Close monitoring of urine output and electrolyte levels is essential to prevent further kidney damage.
6. Liver failure: The patient has cirrhosis, which increases the risk of liver failure. The patient's liver function tests (LFTs) are elevated, and the patient may require further evaluation and management of liver dysfunction.
7. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of septic shock and is receiving vasopressors. Cardiovascular instability can lead to cardiac arrest, and the patient's cardiovascular status should be closely monitored.
8. Infections: The patient is at risk for developing secondary infections, particularly in the respiratory and urinary tracts, due to his immunocompromised state.
9. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient is currently NPO, which may lead to nutritional deficiencies if not addressed promptly.
10. Psychological distress: The patient's critical illness and prolonged hospitalization may lead to psychological distress, including anxiety, depression, and delirium. Close monitoring and support from mental health professionals are essential to prevent and manage these complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - passed RSBI this morning, will trial SBT this morning
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  Is still pending.
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  Will determine course w/ ID.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   - Fix abdominal issues as below
   .
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Continue treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t grim clinical
   scenario
   - NPO for now
   - decompression with GI today
   - If decompression does not work, will consider neostigmine
   .
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fludricortisone 0.1 and hydrocortisone  75 for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today (decided on 75 total)
   .
   #Hct drop: Dropped to 21.2 from 24 this morning.  Rechecked 4 hours
   later and was 23.
   - q8 hour crit
   -<21
 transfusion
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   .
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   - Add lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.
   .
   #Access: L IJ, A line, chemo port and PIV.
   #FEN: replete electrolytes PRN, holding tube feeds because of colonic
   distension.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He has been treated with antibiotics and antivirals, but his respiratory status has not improved significantly. He has developed extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which is being covered with antibiotics. His BAL fluid was inadequate to rule out flu, so oseltamivir is being continued. He has also developed colonic distension, which is being managed with rectal tube placement and antibiotics. His hypotension has improved, but he remains on pressors. He has a low Hct, which is being managed with transfusions. His urine output has improved, but his creatinine is stable. He has anasarca, which is likely due to liver disease. His esophageal cancer is thought to be definitively treated, but he is being followed up with his oncologist.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has not improved significantly, and he remains ventilator-dependent. He may develop further respiratory failure, which could lead to respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely coming from his lungs, and he is at risk of developing further sepsis, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
3. Colonic distension: The patient's colonic distension is being managed with rectal tube placement and antibiotics, but he may develop further complications, such as bowel perforation or abscess.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has improved, but he remains on pressors, and he may develop further hypotension, which could lead to organ dysfunction and death.
5. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is likely due to liver disease, and he may develop further complications, such as ascites or liver failure.
6. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's liver disease may lead to hepatic encephalopathy, which could lead to altered mental status and coma.
7. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing further infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
8. Bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy may lead to bleeding, which could be life-threatening.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antivirals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider further interventions, such as tracheostomy or non-invasive ventilation.
3. Manage the patient's colonic distension with rectal tube placement and antibiotics, and consider further interventions, such as neostigmine or surgery.
4. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with pressors and consider further interventions, such as vasopressin or epinephrine.
5. Monitor the patient's anasarca and consider further interventions, such as diuretics or paracentesis.
6. Monitor the patient's liver function closely and consider further interventions, such as lactulose or rifampicin.
7. Consider further testing, such as echocardiogram or stress test, to assess the patient's cardiac function.
8. Consider further interventions, such as surgery or interventional radiology, to manage the patient's colonic distension or anasarca.

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old man admitted to the ICU with hypoxemic respiratory failure and septic shock. He has a history of cirrhosis, coagulopathy, and adrenal insufficiency. He is currently on mechanical ventilation, vasopressors, and sedation. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 69 bpm, blood pressure of 75/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube, ventilator mode, and FiO2 of 50%. His physical examination reveals right lower extremity edema, left lower extremity edema, and unresponsive movement.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen, leading to increased oxygen requirements, prolonged mechanical ventilation, or even respiratory arrest.
2. Sepsis: The patient's septic shock may lead to organ dysfunction, such as acute kidney injury, liver dysfunction, or cardiovascular instability.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient's coagulopathy may worsen, leading to bleeding complications, such as intracranial hemorrhage or gastrointestinal bleeding.
4. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency may worsen, leading to hypotension, hypoglycemia, or electrolyte imbalance.
5. Cirrhosis: The patient's cirrhosis may lead to portal hypertension, ascites, or hepatic encephalopathy.
6. Catheter-related complications: The patient's indwelling port and arterial line may be associated with bleeding, infection, or thrombosis.
7. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient's mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of VAP, which can lead to pneumonia, sepsis, or respiratory failure.
8. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's coagulopathy and cirrhosis may increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to hypovolemic shock or respiratory failure.
9. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's adrenal insufficiency and cirrhosis may lead to electrolyte imbalance, such as hypokalemia, hypocalcemia, or hyperkalemia.
10. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state may increase the risk of infection, such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or sepsis.

   Assessment and Plan
   58 yo male with esophageal CA in remission and hepatitis C returning to
   the ICU with new hypoxic respiratory failure that has developed in the
   last 12 hours.
   .
   # Respiratory failure: BNP 743 and echo normal, CTA negative, rapidly
   evolving CXRs, appears to be septic from likely pulmonary source.  His
   respiratory status has improved slightly but he remains ventilator
   dependent on assist control.  He has new, extensive ground-glass
   opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which we are
   covering with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.  His BAL fluid was an
   inadequate specimen to rule-out flu, so we are continuing oseltamivir
   for the time being. Checked rheumatoid factor and cryocrit for possible
   pulmonary hemorrhage from cryoglobulinemia given history of Hep C.
   These were both negative.
   - passed RSBI this morning, will trial SBT this morning
   - repeat sputum cultures with endotracheal/mini-BAL sample for flu DFA
   and bacterial culture sent yesterday.  NTD
   - Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Cipro.
   - Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN.
   - Fix abdominal issues as below
   .
   # Colonic distension: Patient
s abdomen is distended though not tense.
   KUB concerning for dramatically distended colon.  C-diff negative.
   Partially improved with rectal tube placement.  Seen by surgery, felt
   he was too high risk to even consider OR (estimated 80% mortality).
   Ddx is obstruction, C.diff mediated megacolon and acute
   pseudo-obstruction ([**Last Name (un) 5975**]
s syndrome). CT scan w/ contrast confirmed
   no anatomic obstruction.  No cause found.  Repeat C. diff negative
   - Stop treating C.Diff w/ IV Flagyl and PO Vanco d/t  3 negative cdiff
   - NPO for now
   - aggressive bowel regimen
   - neostigmine?
   .
   # Hypotension: Has been able to come off of pressors except for
   Levophed and his lactate has improved to normal range.  Appears to have
   relatively normal cardiac function.  His hypotension appears to have
   been from shock, which has improved.  Hypotension multifactorial from
   sepsis, adrenal insufficiency and liver disease.  His sepsis is likely
   coming from his lungs, though we will culture his peritoneal fluid for
   a possible abdominal source.  He did not respond to a cortisol stim
   test [**12-8**], so we are giving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal
   insufficiency.  He does have likely d/t 3rd spacing in the setting of
   malnutrition, liver disease, and cancer.
   - ABx as above
   - Wean levophed further as tolerated.
   - fludricortisone 0.1 and hydrocortisone  75 for adrenal insufficiency
   -Albumin 1g/kg today (decided on 75 total)
   .
   #Hct drop: Dropped to 21.2 from 24 this morning.  Rechecked 4 hours
   later and was 23.
   - q12 hour crit
   -<21
 transfusion
   .
   # Low UOP: Has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is
   stable.  Was likely ischemia in the setting of hypotension from shock.
   .
   #: Anasarca/ Liver disease: Most likely d/t liver disease, although
   cannot r/o some cardiac involvement
   - f/u hepatology recs
   - Albumin 1g/kg today
   - Add lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen
   .
   #: Esophageal CA: thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and
   5-FU.
   - f/u whether Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 1932**] has input.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure.

The patient's current status is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient remains ventilator-dependent on assist control, with new extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia. He is being treated with Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro.
* Cardiovascular: The patient's hypotension appears to have improved, and he has been weaned off pressors except for Levophed. His lactate has improved to normal range, and his cardiac function appears to be relatively normal.
* Gastrointestinal: The patient has colonic distension, which has partially improved with rectal tube placement. He is being treated for possible C. difficile-mediated megacolon and acute pseudo-obstruction.
* Hematological: The patient's Hct has dropped to 21.2 from 24, but has since improved to 23.
* Renal: The patient's urine output has improved with improving hemodynamics, and his creatinine is stable.
* Hepatological: The patient has liver disease, which is likely contributing to his anasarca and low albumin levels.
* Infectious: The patient has a high suspicion of sepsis, likely from a pulmonary source, and is being treated with antibiotics. He also has a possible abdominal source of infection, which is being cultured.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and he may require continued mechanical ventilation and antibiotic therapy.
* Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely to continue, and he may require further antibiotics and treatment.
* C. difficile colitis: The patient's colonic distension may progress to C. difficile colitis, which can lead to severe complications.
* Liver failure: The patient's liver disease may worsen, leading to liver failure and potential multi-organ failure.
* Anasarca: The patient's anasarca may worsen, leading to further fluid accumulation and potential respiratory compromise.
* Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels may become imbalanced, leading to further complications.
* Infection: The patient's infection may spread to other sites, leading to further complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continue Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro for respiratory failure and sepsis
* Continue nebulizers and guaifenisen PRN for respiratory support
* Fix abdominal issues, including colonic distension and possible C. difficile-mediated megacolon
* Continue albumin replacement therapy
* Monitor and manage liver disease
* Monitor and manage anasarca
* Monitor and manage electrolyte levels
* Consider further antibiotics and treatment for sepsis
* Consider further treatment for C. difficile colitis
* Consider further treatment for liver failure
* Consider further treatment for anasarca
* Consider further treatment for electrolyte imbalance

Summary:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who was admitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. He has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation with assist control. His respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent. He has extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggestive of atypical pneumonia, which is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's abdominal distension has improved with rectal tube placement, and C. difficile toxin was negative. He is receiving aggressive bowel regimen and neostigmine is being considered.

He has hypotension, which is multifactorial from sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, and liver disease. He did not respond to a cortisol stim test, so he is receiving fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency.

The patient's Hct has dropped to 21.2 from 24, but has stabilized at 23. He has low urine output, which has improved with improving hemodynamics and stable creatinine.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he may require further interventions to improve oxygenation.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is multifactorial, and he may require further antibiotic treatment and management of underlying sources of infection.
3. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient's adrenal insufficiency is being treated with fluticasone and hydrocortisone, but he may require further monitoring and treatment.
4. Liver disease: The patient's liver disease is likely contributing to his hypotension and may require further management with lactulose and albumin replacement.
5. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is likely due to liver disease, but may also be related to cardiac involvement.
6. C. difficile infection: Although the patient's C. difficile toxin was negative, he may still be at risk for C. difficile infection and require further treatment.
7. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial and may require further management with fluid replacement, vasopressors, and other interventions.
8. Malnutrition: The patient's malnutrition may contribute to his poor respiratory status and require further management with nutrition support.
9. Liver failure: The patient's liver failure may require further management with lactulose, albumin replacement, and other interventions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue mechanical ventilation with assist control to improve oxygenation.
2. Continue antibiotic treatment for sepsis and atypical pneumonia.
3. Monitor and manage adrenal insufficiency with fluticasone and hydrocortisone.
4. Manage liver disease with lactulose and albumin replacement.
5. Monitor and manage anasarca with fluid replacement and other interventions.
6. Consider C. difficile treatment if symptoms persist.
7. Monitor and manage hypotension with fluid replacement, vasopressors, and other interventions.
8. Provide nutrition support to manage malnutrition.
9. Consider liver transplantation if liver failure is severe and not reversible.

Based on the patient's daily progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, but they remain ventilator-dependent. The presence of extensive ground-glass opacities on CT scan suggests atypical pneumonia, which may worsen their respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to a pulmonary source, and they have been treated with antibiotics. However, the source of sepsis is not yet identified, and further cultures and testing are needed to determine the causative organism.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is multifactorial, caused by sepsis, adrenal insufficiency, and liver disease. They have been treated with corticosteroids and vasopressors, but their blood pressure remains unstable.
4. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is likely caused by liver disease, although some cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out. They have been treated with diuretics and albumin, but their edema persists.
5. Colonic distension: The patient's colonic distension is likely caused by obstruction, C. difficile-mediated megacolon, or acute pseudo-obstruction. They have been treated with rectal tube placement, antibiotics, and bowel regimen, but their distension persists.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte imbalance is likely caused by their liver disease, sepsis, and diuretic use. They have been treated with electrolyte supplements, but their electrolyte levels remain abnormal.
7. Blood product transfusion: The patient has received multiple blood product transfusions, which may increase their risk of transfusion-related complications, such as transfusion-associated circulatory overload or allergic reactions.
8. Infection: The patient has been treated with antibiotics for suspected sepsis, but their infection status is not yet fully resolved. Further cultures and testing are needed to determine the presence of infection and to guide antibiotic therapy.
9. Liver disease: The patient's liver disease is likely contributing to their anasarca, electrolyte imbalance, and other complications. They have been treated with diuretics, albumin, and lactulose, but their liver function remains abnormal.
10. Esophageal cancer: The patient has a history of esophageal cancer, which has been treated with cisplatin and 5-FU. However, their cancer status is not fully resolved, and further evaluation and treatment may be needed.

Overall, the patient's medical complications are complex and multifactorial, and they require ongoing monitoring and treatment to manage their various conditions.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with esophageal cancer in remission and hepatitis C, who has been readmitted to the ICU with new-onset hypoxic respiratory failure. The patient's respiratory status has improved slightly, but he remains ventilator-dependent on assist control.

The patient has been diagnosed with septic shock, likely due to a pulmonary source, and is being treated with antibiotics (Vanc/Meropenem/Flagyl/Cipro). He has also been diagnosed with atypical pneumonia, which is being covered with antibiotics.

The patient's abdominal issues include colonic distension, which has been partially improved with rectal tube placement. A CT scan with contrast confirmed no anatomic obstruction, and the diagnosis is likely obstruction, C. difficile-mediated megacolon, or acute pseudo-obstruction. The patient is being treated with IV Flagyl and PO Vanco.

The patient's hypotension has improved, and his lactate has returned to normal. He is being treated with fluticasone and hydrocortisone for adrenal insufficiency, and his sepsis is being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's Hct has dropped to 21.2, but rechecked 4 hours later and was 23. He is being transfused with q8 hour crit.

The patient's low urine output has improved with improving hemodynamics and creatinine is stable. His anasarca/liver disease is likely due to liver disease, although cardiac involvement cannot be ruled out. He is being treated with f/u hepatology recs, Albumin 1g/kg, and Add lactulose for liver disease and bowel regimen.

The patient's esophageal CA is thought to be definitively treated with cisplatin and 5-FU, and his access includes L IJ, A line, chemo port, and PIV.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and he is still ventilator-dependent. He is at risk of further respiratory deterioration.
2. Sepsis: The patient's sepsis is likely due to a pulmonary source, and he is at risk of further deterioration.
3. Abdominal complications: The patient's colonic distension and C. difficile-mediated megacolon are ongoing concerns, and he is at risk of further abdominal complications.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension has improved, but he is at risk of further episodes.
5. Adrenal insufficiency: The patient is being treated for adrenal insufficiency, but he is at risk of further adrenal crisis.
6. Liver disease: The patient's liver disease is ongoing, and he is at risk of further liver dysfunction.
7. Anasarca: The patient's anasarca is likely due to liver disease, but he is at risk of further fluid accumulation.
8. C. difficile infection: The patient's C. difficile infection is ongoing, and he is at risk of further complications.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilation settings as necessary.
3. Continue to treat the patient's abdominal issues, including colonic distension and C. difficile-mediated megacolon.
4. Monitor the patient's hypotension and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to treat the patient's adrenal insufficiency.
6. Monitor the patient's liver disease and adjust treatment as necessary.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's anasarca and adjust treatment as necessary.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's C. difficile infection and adjust treatment as necessary.

Based on the patient's progress note, the patient is a 24-hour-old ICU patient with a chief complaint of respiratory failure and shock, which has been resolved. The patient underwent a colonoscopy with decompression, which was negative for C. diff.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.4°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 123/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 27 inspirations per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on 50% FiO2. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, peak inspiratory pressure of 16 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 8 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 3.7, hemoglobin of 7.8 g/dL, platelet count of 24 K/uL, and creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL. The patient's blood cultures are pending.

The patient's physical examination reveals a thin individual with normal cardiovascular and respiratory examinations. The patient has soft, non-tender abdominal examination and 1+ edema in both lower extremities. The patient is unable to stand and has normal muscle tone.

The patient's diagnosis includes shock, septic, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), constipation, pleural disease, and pain control. The patient is at risk for potential medical complications, including:

1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) due to prolonged mechanical ventilation.
2. Catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) due to indwelling urinary catheter.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to immobility and risk factors.
4. Stress ulcer bleeding due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and risk factors.
5. Aspiration pneumonia due to altered mental status and risk factors.
6. Sepsis due to ongoing septic shock and risk factors.
7. Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypovolemia and risk factors.
8. Pneumonia due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and risk factors.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continuation of mechanical ventilation with close monitoring of respiratory status.
2. Administration of antibiotics and antifungals as per sepsis protocol.
3. Aggressive fluid resuscitation and vasopressor support as needed.
4. Close monitoring of laboratory results, including blood cultures, and adjusting antibiotics and antifungals as per results.
5. Prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer bleeding, and VAP.
6. Nutrition and glycemic control as per protocol.
7. Regular reassessment of pain control and adjustment as needed.
8. Close monitoring of patient's mental status and adjusting sedation as needed.

The patient's code status is "full code," and the patient's disposition is ICU. The total time spent in the ICU is unknown.
